section.title: Reading Assignment
section.p: Also, turn in solutions to these exercises:

statement.p:
Consider the operation \square on the positive integers defined by a \square b = a+b-1.
Is \square associative?
Does \square have an identity in the positive integers?
Does \square have the inverse property?

li.p:
Yes, it is associative:
(a \squareb)\square c= (a+b-1)\square c = a+b-1+c-1 = a+b+c-2 a \square(b \square c)= a \square(b+c-1) = a+(b+c-1)-1 = a+b+c-2
If e is an identity, we would need a \square e=a+e-1 = a. Solving a+e-1 = a for e, we see that 1 is an identity.

No, the inverse of a postitive integer a would be b such that a \square b=1. Therefore a+b-1=1, or b=-a+2. But since we assume a is a positive integer b is not positive unless a = 1, and so only 1 have an inverse.
